question: Watson-Jones approach is done for?
exp: (d) Hip replacement- Watson-Jones operation is anterolateral approach to the hip joint. There are four commonly used approaches to the hip joint:- Anterior or Smith-Peterson- commonly used to access the hip in cases of suspected septic arthritis - Anterolateral or Watson-Jones- is used for hemi or total hip arthroplasty - Direct lateral or Hardinge - Posterior or Southern approach
topic_name: Congenital Talips Eqino Varvs (C. T. E. V.)

question: Which of the following is not a typical deformity seen in congenital tali pes equinovarus?
exp: Ans. B. Forefoot pronation. Congenital tali pes equinovarus (clubfoot) is a deformity of the foot with an incidence of 1 in 250-1000. It is more common in males and is often bilateral. There may be associated musculoskeletal anomalies. A number of deformities are seen: forefoot adduction (tibialis posterior), forefoot supination (tibialis anterior), midfoot cavus (intrinsic, flexor hallucis longus, flexor digitorum longus), hindfoot varus (Achilles tendon, tibialis posterior) and hindfoot equinus (Achilles tendon). Dr Ponseti has revolutionized the treatment of clubfoot from a surgical (posteromedial release) to a non-surgical one (serial casting).
topic_name: Congenital Talips Eqino Varvs (C. T. E. V.)

question: Triple orthodesis consists of fusion of which three joints of foot?
exp: Ans. a (Subtalar + Calcaneocuboid + Talonavicular joints)# Subtalar joint is talocalcaneocuboid (TCC) joint. (TCC-CCTN =>Talo. Calcaneo. Cuboid + Calcaneo. Cuboid +Talo. Navicular joints). (Mnemonic: TCC-CCTN). TRIPLE ORTHODESIS# Used in treatment of CTEV (Congenital talipes equino vrtfus).# Performed after the age of 12 years.
topic_name: Congenital Talips Eqino Varvs (C. T. E. V.)

question: What is the treatment for a newborn child with CTEV?
exp: Ans. is 'b' i. e., Manipulation and strapping or serial cast Treatment of CTEV in new born: o Treatment should begin early, preferably within a day or two of birth (as early as possible or when the newborn presents to the surgeon). o This consists of repeated manipula- tion and adhesive strapping that maintains the correction; the manipulations are taught to the child's mother, who is then able to carry out gentle stretches on a regular basis with the strapping still in place. o Treatment is supervised by a physiotherapist, who alters the strapping as correction is gradually obtained, o If this level of care is not available, it may be better to hold position by applying a light plaster cast (over a protective layer of strapping), which is soaked off and changed every week.
opb: Manipulation and strapping or serial cast
topic_name: Congenital Talips Eqino Varvs (C. T. E. V.)

question: Most common cause of CTEV -
exp: Ans. is 'c' i. e., Idiopathic Causes of CTEVo CTEV may be either primary or secondary. Primary or Idiopathic. It is the most common type of CTEVFoot deformity (CTEV) is the only manifestation, otherwise musculoskeletal system is normal. Secondary. CTEV is a local manifestation of a systemic syndrome. Causes are. Neurological disorders & neural tube defects eg myelomeningocele, & spinal dysraphism. Paralytic disorder (due to muscular imbalance) as polio, spina bifida, myelodysplasia, & Fredreich's ataxia. Arthrogryposis multiplexa. Larsen syndrome. Freeman- sheldon syndrome. Diastrophic dwarfism. Sacral agenesis, tibial deficiency, constriction rings & amniotic bands
topic_name: Congenital Talips Eqino Varvs (C. T. E. V.)

question: Ideal age for PMSTR is -
exp: Ans. is 'b' i. e., 1-3 years PMSTR: Posteromedial Soft tissue release:* It is the soft tissue surgical treatment for Congenital Talipes. Equinovarus.* The results of early operation for treatment of congentialtalipesequino varus, in particular neonatal surgery, have not been shown to be better than those of late surgery.* Delaying surgery until the child is near walking age has the advantage of operating of larger foot (making surgery easier).* Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR), (Turcos) is best done at young age (1-3 years).* Posterior release or complete subtalar release can also be performed.* But in children older than 3 years of age lateral column shortening procedures are often performed in conjunction with posteromedial soft tissue release.
topic_name: Congenital Talips Eqino Varvs (C. T. E. V.)

question: CTEV is
exp: [C) (Congenital deformity): (203- Maheshwari 4th edition). Congenital talipes equinovarus (Idiopathic club foot)* Polygenic pattern of inheritance* Identical deformities occur with myelomeningocele (Spinabifida) and in arthrogrposis. Clinical Features* Foot is both turned and twisted inwards so that the sole faces posteromedially* Ankle is in equinus* Heal is inverted* Forefoot is adducted and supinated* Cavus as well* Talus may protrude on the dorsolateral surface of the foot* Heel is usually small and high* Call may be thin
topic_name: Congenital Talips Eqino Varvs (C. T. E. V.)

question: Commonest congenital deformity is
exp: B. (Congenital club foot) (613 - 614 - CDT-4th). Metatarsus adductus (metatarsus varus) is the most common foot deformity in the newborn infant (occurring 5 in 1000 live birth). The hallmark of metatarsus adductus is medial deviation of the forefoot.* Congenital club foot incidence 1 in 1000 live birth* Congenitl hand diffence occursin 1 in 1500 live birth* Commonest cause of shaft femur under 2 years age is child abuse (700- Apley 8th)* Screening test used in newborn with club foot -- Inability to ** dorsiflex and evert the dorsum of foot so as to touch the shin*** Ganglions are the most common soft tissue tumours of the hand and wrist**Pectoralis major muscle most commonly affected by congenitally absence (599 - Apley 8th)
topic_name: Congenital Talips Eqino Varvs (C. T. E. V.)

question: Ponsetti technique failure in children should be managed with -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., Posteromedial soft tissue release * If treatment by manipulation and retention fails, operation should usually be undertaken before 9 months of age, mostly at 4-6 months. The idea behind early operation is to set the tarsal bones in normal relationship to one another and to remove deforming forces, thus allowing the bones to develop in their normal shape from an early age. The procedure used is soft tissue release, i. e. postero-medial release (PMR). The taut structures on the postero-medial side are released.
opd: Lateral closing wedge osteotomy of calcaneum
topic_name: Congenital Talips Eqino Varvs (C. T. E. V.)
